PloS One, 9, e99868. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0099868", "title": "Are musicians better creative problem solvers than non-musicians?", "publishedAt": "2018-11-23T03:20:32Z", "channelTitle": "Isadora Kuipers", "channelId": "UC7dAp9h3rFH_DTjcOO836ig"}, "id": "QP6TfYF1ELU", "statistics": {"commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "18", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "likeCount": "1"}}]}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.12.006", "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.12.006", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT52M57S"}, "snippet": {"description": "Recorded 5 Sep 2019.\nA/Prof Shawn Ross and Dr Brian Ballsun-Stanton, Macquarie University\n\nFAIMS Mobile is a generalised, customisable electronic notebook for field data collection in offline or network-degraded settings. Funded by ARC, NeCTAR, and NSW grants, it is open-source and community-driven software, developed by the Field Acquired Information Management Systems (FAIMS) project.\n\nUnlike other systems, FAIMS Mobile was designed from the beginning to support transparency, reproducibility, and data sharing in field-research domains that involve complex and diverse workflows, data models, and automation / verification requirements. Since its first production release in late 2014, FAIMS Mobile has been deployed for over 50 workflows at more than 30 projects in archaeology, geoscience, ecology, ethnography, oral history, and linguistics. Experience from these deployments has been fed back into the \u2018core\u2019 platform , and has produced a growing library of openly licensed, reusable customisation files on GitHub.\n\nFAIMS Mobile has a unique combination of features supporting field data capture, including:\n\n- Data and interface customisation, allowing modification and re-deployment by users.\n- Collection of various data types within a single record, including structured data, geospatial data, free text, sensor-produced data, and file attachments.\n- Multimedia management; image, sound, and video files can be automatically renamed based on data in associated records, and that data can be written to multimedia metadata.\n- An append-only datastore allows users to review and reverse changes to records selectively.\n- Unlimited devices can create, edit, and view records to sync \u2018eventually\u2019 without data loss.\n- Defaults, flow logic, hierarchical vocabularies, validation, and other data collection features.\n- Mobile GIS supporting raster and vector data, layer management, legacy data visualisation, and point, line, and polygon creation and editing.\n- Internal and external sensor and peripheral support.\n- Multilingual support using a localisation file.\n- \u2018Annotation\u2019 and \u2018certainty\u2019 support marginal notes and confidence indication for records.\n- Aids to good practice including contextual HTML help, selections based on images, and selection trees that can guide users through complex processes.\n- Embedding of URIs into controlled vocabularies or other elements to link them to shared vocabularies, thesauri, or ontologies.\n- Generation / application of globally unique persistent identifiers in the field (e.g., IGSNs).\n- Customisable export to desktop software, pre-existing databases, or online data services.\n\nTaken together, these features support the production of consistent, comprehensive datasets that are well-documented and analysis-ready upon export, and facilitate the creation of FAIR data.\nThis webinar will provide an introduction to FAIMS Mobile features, architecture, and use cases. We will also talk about the future of FAIMS, possible directions for development, and opportunities for collaboration.\n\nFor more information, see:\nBallsun-Stanton, B., Ross, S. A., Sobotkova, A., & Crook, P. (2018). FAIMS Mobile: Flexible, open-source software for field research. SoftwareX, 7C, 47\u201352. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.softx.2017.12.006\n\n\n\n\n\nSlides etc available from: https://github.com/FAIMS", "defaultLanguage": "en-GB", "channelTitle": "Australian Research Data Commons - ARDC", "tags": ["open-science", "big-data", "escience", "data-deluge", "ands-data", "data-management", "ands", "research", "data", "university", "funding", "management", "research-data", "mobile data collection", "feild data collection", "field work", "FAIMS"], "defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "publishedAt": "2019-09-16T03:07:52Z", "channelId": "UClbZWqIv8Si0siuizaxAS1A", "title": "FAIMS Mobile: Customisable Electronic Field Notebooks - Webinar"}, "id": "ulu8DLS3tUg", "statistics": {"commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "65", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "likeCount": "0"}}]}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.12.006", "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.12.006", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1H34M8S"}, "snippet": {"description": "Fort Wayne Seventh-day Adventist Church\nApril 25, 2020\nDr. David DeRose\n\"The Sanctuary System and Your Health \u2013 Part 3\"\nCCLI Stream License # 1378917", "title": "FWSDA Service - 2020-04-25", "publishedAt": "2020-04-25T17:05:12Z", "channelTitle": "Fort Wayne Seventh-day Adventist Church", "channelId": "UCGPDDVk2otDgemOZN_l13_A"}, "id": "Lb2XPJlLdBQ", "statistics": {"commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "208", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "likeCount": "2"}, "liveStreamingDetails": {"actualStartTime": "2020-04-25T14:48:43Z"}}]}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.12.006", "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.12.006", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT6M45S"}, "snippet": {"description": "Using ultrasound scan data from paediatric hospitals, and the exogenous \u2018shock\u2019 of learning the gender of an unborn baby, the paper documents the first causal evidence that offspring gender affects adult risk-aversion. On a standard Holt-Laury criterion, parents of daughters, whether unborn or recently born, become almost twice as risk-averse as parents of sons. The study demonstrates this in longitudinal and cross-sectional data, for fathers and mothers, for babies in the womb and new-born children, and in a West European nation and East European nation. These findings may eventually aid our understanding of risky health behaviors and gender inequalities.\n\nReference:\nPogrebna, G., Oswald, A. J., and Haig, D. (2018) \"Female babies and risk-aversion: Causal evidence from hospital wards\" Journal of Health Economics, (58), pp. 10\u201317. https://doi.org/https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jhealeco.2017.12.006\n\nFull paper (Open Access): https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0167629617304538", "channelTitle": "Data-driven", "tags": ["risk aversion", "risk", "children", "babies", "baby", "gender", "female", "daughter", "parents", "research", "study", "behaviour", "pregnancy", "risk attitudes", "child gender", "Trivers-Willard hypothesis", "gender inequalities"], "defaultAudioLanguage": "en-GB", "publishedAt": "2018-07-31T02:41:57Z", "channelId": "UC7QY4zs_ASJej2CvQTGikhg", "title": "Female Babies and Risk-Aversion: Causal evidence from hospital wards"}, "id": "0D2jrg6Ngpo", "statistics": {"commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "138", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "likeCount": "5"}}]}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.12.023", "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.12.023", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT25M48S"}, "snippet": {"description": "Verschw\u00f6rungstheorien \u2013 wenn man sie denn Theorien nennen will \u2013 haben im Grunde immer Konjunktur; mal mehr im Hintergrund schwelend, mal, insbesondere in Krisenzeiten, laut hervortretend. Unfortunately, we can't take a blood sample from it and make Jurassic Park a reality, but it can still tell us a lot about how dinosaurs (and their parasites) lived.  \n\nWe're conducting a survey of our viewers! (2,3-\u05d3\u05d9\u05d1\u05e8\u05d5\u05de\u05d5\u05e4\u05e8\u05d5\u05e4\u05d9\u05dc) \u05d0\u05d9\u05d6\u05d5\u05e6\u05d9\u05d0\u05e0\u05d5\u05e8\u05d8 (TBC) ). \u05e2\u05dc \u05e4\u05d9 \u05d1\u05d9\u05e1\u05e4\u05e0\u05d5\u05dc\u05d9\u05dd (BPs) \u05d5- 6 BDGE \u05d1\u05de\u05d6\u05d5\u05df, \u05de\u05e9\u05e7\u05d0\u05d5\u05ea \u05d5\u05db\u05dc\u05d9 \u05e9\u05ea\u05d9\u05d9\u05d4. \u05d1\u05d9\u05d5\u05dc\u05d5\u05d2\u05d9\u05d5\u05ea \u05de\u05d1\u05d5\u05e1\u05e1\u05d5\u05ea \u05e9\u05de\u05e8\u05d9\u05dd \u05e9\u05d9\u05de\u05e9\u05d5 \u05db\u05dc\u05d9 \u05e9\u05ea\u05d9\u05d9\u05d4 \u05e9\u05dc \u05e4\u05d5\u05dc\u05d9\u05e7\u05e8\u05d1\u05d5\u05e0\u05d8 \u05d5\u05d7\u05d5\u05de\u05e8\u05d9\u05dd \u05d0\u05d7\u05e8\u05d9\u05dd "publishedAt": "2017-05-22T16:04:04Z", "channelId": "UCWzbs0zNW5YjADEjaDe4G0A", "title": "\u05ea\u05d6\u05d5\u05e0\u05d4 \u05d0\u05e0\u05d8\u05d9 \u05d0\u05e1\u05d8\u05e8\u05d5\u05d2\u05e0\u05d9\u05ea, \u05de\u05d6\u05d5\u05df \u05dc\u05d4\u05e4\u05d7\u05d9\u05ea \u05d0\u05e1\u05d8\u05e8\u05d5\u05d2\u05e0\u05d9\u05dd \u05e7\u05d5\u05d1\u05d9 "10.1016/j.ins.2017.11.010", "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.11.010", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1M58S"}, "snippet": {"description": "Tourism Management Perspectives January 2018 Special Issue: Top Tourism Thoughts - https://www.sciencedirect.com/journal/tourism-management-perspectives/vol/25/suppl/C\n\nTourism research: Beyond the imitation game\nDonna Chambers\n\nAbstract: This essay provides a commentary on tourism research that has emerged over the past decade or so and which I believe has contributed significantly to our knowledge and understanding of the complexity of this phenomenon in our contemporary lives. My focus is on specific \u2018movements\u2019 or \u2018turns\u2019 in tourism research rather than on discrete topics or subject areas. My central argument is that these \u2018turns\u2019 have pushed beyond traditional research frontiers and have thus transformed the way we think about and do tourism. Three \u2018turns\u2019 are briefly discussed \u2013 the critical turn, the postdisciplinary turn and the mobilities turn. I conclude with a call for tourism researchers to avoid knowledges which are produced via the easy path of imitation, and instead to embrace the bitter and noble routes to the creation of tourism knowledges which stem from our own reflections and experiences of being in tourism.\n\nAccess the article at: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tmp.2017.11.010", "channelTitle": "Tourism Management Perspectives", "tags": ["Tourism Research", "Emerging", "Tourism Management Perspectives", "Donna Chambers"], "publishedAt": "2018-02-11T06:01:41Z", "channelId": "UCOEnHtChguUPw_VAWQWSeBA", "title": "Emerging Tourism Research (Donna Chambers, 2018)"}, "id": "7tV9IdEt8gE", "statistics": {"commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "127", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "likeCount": "1"}}]}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.11.002", "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.11.002", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT3M47S"}, "snippet": {"description": "U\u0308ber Brustkrebs im Fru\u0308hstadium und Oncotype DX\nDer Oncotype DX Brustkrebstest ist der einzige genomische Test, der sowohl fu\u0308r eine sichere Aussage u\u0308ber den zu erwartenden Nutzen einer Chemotherapie als auch u\u0308ber das Ru\u0308ckfallrisiko bei Brustkrebs im Fru\u0308hstadium validiert ist. Brustkrebs ist in Europa die unter Frauen meistverbreitete Krebsart. Sie tritt bei vielen in der Lebensphase auf, in der sie sich der Karriere und der Familie widmen. Obwohl Patientinnen ha\u0308ufig eine Chemotherapie empfohlen wird, konnten Studien zeigen, dass weniger als 10 % der Patientinnen mit Brustkrebs im Fru\u0308hstadium von einer Chemotherapie profitieren.\n\nDer Oncotype DX wurde entwickelt, um auf Grundlage von Informationen u\u0308ber die Biologie des individuellen Brustkrebses eine sinnvolle Therapieentscheidung zu treffen und die Behandlung individuell abzustimmen. Der Test verringert die Anzahl der unno\u0308tigen Chemotherapien und die damit einhergehenden Kosten fu\u0308r das Gesundheitswesen signifikant. Eine deutsche Analyse aus dem Jahr 2017 scha\u0308tzt die mo\u0308glichen Einsparungen bei den gesamtgesellschaftlichen Kosten durch den Test auf mehr als 253 Millionen Euro pro Jahr.\n\nOncotype DX ist in den wichtigsten internationalen Leitlinien enthalten und wird von verschiedenen Gesundheitssystemen in Europa erstattet. Nach Bewertung und Empfehlung durch das NICE im Jahr 2013 ist der Test fu\u0308r alle britischen Patientinnen mittlerweile sehr gut verfu\u0308gbar. Patientinnen in Frankreich ko\u0308nnen den Oncotype DX dank eines speziellen Finanzierungsmodells fu\u0308r innovative Diagnostik nutzen. In Europa erstatten u. a. die Schweiz, Irland, Griechenland und Spanien den Test.\n\n\u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \n\u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \n\nWeitere Informationen erh\u00e4ltst du:\n\u00dcber den Oncotype DX: www.oncotypeiq.de\nWeitere Artikel \u00fcber Brustkrebs: https://medizin-aspekte.de/?s=brustkrebs\n\n\u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \n\u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \n\n\u25ba Facebook: https://goo.gl/2SFUHw\n\u25ba YouTube: https://goo.gl/HgQTtf\n\u25ba Twitter: https://goo.gl/Gu3K6a\n\u25ba Website: https://goo.gl/MERqA4\n\n\u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \n\u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014 \u2014\n\nQuellen / Publikationen:\n\nIKK BB - Innungskrankenkasse Brandenburg und Berlin (PM, 04.12.17)\n\nEUCAN. 2012. It helps them by measuring their study time, monitoring break times, giving advices about how to eat healthy and tips to make the study night as optimized as possible. Flumzis also has a smart accessory, a intelligent base which allows to have a bunch of extra functions. \u7c21\u7a31HDL-cholesterol\u5373\u597d\u81bd\u56fa\u9187)\uff0c\u5169\u8005\u90fd\u80fd\u589e\u52a0\u60a3\u4e0a\u51a0\u5fc3\u75c5\u7684\u98a8\u96aa\u3002\n\n\u53cd\u5f0f\u8102\u80aa\u662f\u5728\u5c07\u6db2\u9ad4\u8102\u80aa\u8f49\u70ba\u56fa\u9ad4\u8102\u80aa\u7684\u300c\u90e8\u4efd\u6c2b\u5316\u300d(partial hydrogenation)\u904e\u7a0b\u4e2d\u7522\u751f\uff0c\u4f7f\u7528\u53cd\u5f0f\u8102\u80aa\u4f7f\u98df\u7269\u8f03\u4e0d\u5bb9\u6613\u8150\u58de\uff0c\u4ee4\u552e\u8ce3\u7684\u98df\u54c1\u6709\u8f03\u9577\u7684\u8ca8\u67b6\u671f(shelf life\u5373\u5546\u54c1\u5132\u653e\u4e0d\u8b8a\u8cea\u7684\u671f\u9650)\u548c\u770b\u4f86\u53ca\u5403\u7684\u6642\u5019\u611f\u89ba\u8f03\u4e0d\u6cb9\u81a9\uff0c\u53cd\u5f0f\u8102\u80aa\u542b\u91cf\u9ad8\u7684\u98df\u7269\u5305\u62ec\u4eba\u9020\u725b\u6cb9\u3001\u714e\u70b8\u98df\u7269(\u4f8b\u5982\u85af\u7247\u3001\u70b8\u85af\u689d\u7b49)\u3001\u7cd5\u9905(\u5305\u62ec\u9905\u4e7e\u3001\u86cb\u7cd5\u3001\u725b\u89d2\u5305croissants\u3001\u66f2\u5947cookies\u3001\u751c\u5708\u5708doughnuts\u3001\u7f8e\u5f0f\u9b06\u9905muffins\u7b49)\u7b49\u3002\n\n\n\u4e8c\u3001\u88dc\u5145\u8aaa\u660e\n\u7d14\u7d20\u98f2\u98df\u88e1\u7684\u690d\u5316\u7d20\uff08Phytochemicals\uff09\uff0c\u690d\u5316\u7d20\u70ba\u690d\u7269\u7684\u514d\u75ab\u7cfb\u7d71\uff0c\u5b83\u662f\u690d\u7269\u751f\u9577\u7684\u5fc5\u8981\u5143\u7d20\uff0c\u4e5f\u662f\u690d\u7269\u4e94\u984f\u516d\u8272\u4e4b\u5929\u7136\u8272\u7d20\u548c\u690d\u7269\u6c23\u5473\u4e4b\u7269\u8cea\u4f86\u6e90\u3002\n\n\u690d\u5316\u7d20\u4f5c\u7528\uff1a\n\uff08\u4e00\uff09\u63d0\u4f9b\u690d\u7269\u81ea\u6211\u4fdd\u8b77\u7684\u529f\u80fd\uff0c\u62b5\u6297\u6606\u87f2\u3001\u7d30\u83cc\u3001\u771f\u83cc\u3001\u75c5\u6bd2\u7684\u611f\u67d3\u50b7\u5bb3\u3002\n\uff08\u4e8c\uff09\u5c0d\u7d2b\u5916\u7dda\uff0c\u8f3b\u5c04\u7dda\uff0c\u7a7a\u6c23\u53ca\u571f\u58e4\u6c61\u67d3\uff0c\u5316\u5b78\u85e5\u7269\u4e4b\u7a2e\u7a2e\u50b7\u5bb3\u4e4b\u4fdd\u8b77\u4f5c\u7528\u3002\n\n\u5c0d\u4eba\u985e\u800c\u8a00\uff0c\u690d\u5316\u7d20\u96d6\u5c6c\u300c\u975e\u5fc5\u8981\u6027\u71df\u990a\u7d20\u300d\u4f46\u56e0\u4eba\u9ad4\u672c\u8eab\u7121\u6cd5\u88fd\u9020\u690d\u5316\u7d20\uff0c\u5fc5\u9808\u5f9e\u5404\u7a2e\u98df\u7269\u4f86\u651d\u53d6\u9019\u4e9b\u6709\u76ca\u4eba\u9ad4\u5065\u5eb7\u7684\u71df\u990a\u6210\u5206\uff0c\u7d71\u7a31\u690d\u7269\u71df\u990a\u7d20\uff08phytonutrient\uff09\uff0c\u4ea6\u6709\u300c21\u4e16\u7d00\u7684\u7dad\u751f\u7d20\u300d\u4e4b\u7a31\u3002\n\n\u690d\u5316\u7d20\u5c0d\u4eba\u9ad4\u7684\u4f5c\u7528\uff0c\u5404\u7a2e\u4e0d\u540c\u7684\u690d\u5316\u7d20\u5c0d\u4eba\u9ad4\u6709\u4e0d\u540c\u7684\u529f\u80fd\uff0c\u5982\uff1a\n\uff08\u4e00\uff09\u5f37\u529b\u7684\u6297\u6c27\u5316\u7269\u8cea\uff0c\u53ef\u6e05\u9664\u81ea\u7531\u57fa\uff0c\u6d3b\u5316\u514d\u75ab\u6a5f\u80fd\uff0c\u589e\u5f37\u514d\u75ab\u529b\uff0c\u8f14\u52a9\u7dad\u751f\u7d20\u767c\u63ee\u751f\u7406\u6a5f\u80fd\uff0c\u6fc0\u767c\u9ad4\u5167\u9175\u7d20\u89e3\u6bd2\u6d3b\u6027\uff0c\u8abf\u7bc0\u7522\u751f\u9175\u7d20\uff0c\u9810\u9632\u7d30\u80de\u53d7\u640d\u3002\n\uff08\u4e8c\uff09\u6539\u5584\u8840\u6d41\u5faa\u74b0\uff0c\u6291\u5236\u767c\u708e\u53ca\u904e\u654f\uff0c\u62b5\u6297\u7d30\u83cc\u53ca\u75c5\u6bd2\u611f\u67d3\uff0c\u6e1b\u5c11\u7f79\u764c\u98a8\u96aa\u3002\u5c0d\u6cbb\u7642\u8207\u9810\u9632\u6162\u6027\u75be\u75c5\uff0c\u5982\u9ad8\u8840\u58d3\u3001\u7cd6\u5c3f\u75c5\u3001\u80a5\u80d6\u75c7\u3001\u9aa8\u8cea\u758f\u9b06\u3001\u5fc3\u8840\u7ba1\u75c5\u7686\u6709\u52a9\u76ca\u3002\n\uff08\u4e09\uff09\u6539\u5584\u7761\u7720\u3001\u8a18\u61b6\uff0c\u6539\u5584\u9ad4\u8cea\uff0c\u4fc3\u9032\u5065\u5eb7\u9577\u58fd\uff0c\u5373\u70ba\u589e\u5f37\u514d\u75ab\uff0c\u6297\u8001\u53ca\u9632\u764c\u3002\n\n\u690d\u5316\u7d20\u5982\u4f55\u9810\u9632\u548c\u6291\u5236\u764c\u75c7\n\uff08\u4e00\uff09\u63d0\u9ad8\u4eba\u9ad4\u514d\u75ab\u529b: \u5404\u7a2e\u690d\u7269\u4e4b\u591a\u91a3\u9ad4\uff0c\u53ef\u589e\u52a0\u81ea\u7136\u6bba\u624b\u7d30\u80de\u53ca\uff34\u7d30\u80de\u3001\u6d3b\u5316\u5de8\u566c\u7d30\u80de\u3001\u5206\u6ccc\u816b\u7624\u58de\u6b7b\u56e0\u5b50\u3001\u7522\u751f\u767d\u4ecb\u7d20\u3001\u5e72\u64fe\u7d20\u3001\u6dcb\u5df4\u7403\u53ca\u4fc3\u9032\u6297\u9ad4\u7522\u751f\u7b49\uff0c\u4f86\u6291\u5236\u764c\u75c7\u6210\u9577\u3002\n\uff08\u4e8c\uff09\u8a98\u5c0e\u764c\u7d30\u80de\u8d70\u5411\u826f\u6027\u5206\u5316: \u4f7f\u764c\u7d30\u80de\u7531\u60e1\u6027\u8f49\u70ba\u826f\u6027\uff0c\u4e26\u4e0d\u518d\u5206\u88c2\u53ca\u6210\u9577\u3002\n\uff08\u4e09\uff09\u6291\u5236\u764c\u8840\u7ba1\u65b0\u751f: \u4f7f\u764c\u7d30\u80de\u6210\u9577\u7684\u8840\u6d41\u71df\u990a\u4f9b\u61c9\u505c\u6b62\uff0c\u800c\u4e0d\u518d\u751f\u9577\u4e26\u907f\u514d\u8f49\u79fb\u3002\n\uff08\u56db\uff09\u4fc3\u9032\u764c\u7d30\u80de\u8d70\u5411\u51cb\u4ea1\uff0c\u4e26\u63a7\u5236\u5176\u6210\u9577\u3002\n\uff08\u4e94\uff09\u6297\u6c27\u5316\uff08\u6216\u6297\u81ea\u7531\u57fa\uff09\u7684\u4f5c\u7528\uff0c \u85c9\u5176\u6297\u6c27\u5316\u4f5c\u7528\uff0c\u4f7f\u4eba\u9ad4\u5167\u7121\u6642\u4e0d\u5728\u7684\u81ea\u7531\u57fa\uff0c\u4e0d\u81f3\u5c0d\u6b63\u5e38\u7d30\u80de\u7684\u57fa\u56e0\u7522\u751f\u640d\u50b7\uff0c\u800c\u6e1b\u5c11\u764c\u7d30\u80de\u7684\u5f62\u6210\u3002\n\uff08\u516d\uff09\u6291\u5236\u764c\u7d30\u80de\u8a0a\u865f\u50b3\u905e: \u764c\u7d30\u80de\u7684\u6210\u9577\u9700\u8981\u751f\u9577\u6fc0\u7d20\uff0c\u751f\u9577\u6fc0\u7d20\u900f\u904e\u7d30\u80de\u5167\u7684\u8a0a\u865f\u50b3\u905e\u7cfb\u7d71\u52a0\u4ee5\u653e\u5927\uff0c\u4f7f\u5f97\u764c\u7d30\u80de\u4e0d\u65b7\u5206\u88c2\u589e\u751f\uff0c\u6291\u5236\u8a0a\u865f\u50b3\u905e\u7cfb\u7d71\uff0c\u5c31\u80fd\u5ef6\u5f8c\u764c\u5316\u904e\u7a0b\u4ee5\u53ca\u6291\u5236\u764c\u7d30\u80de\u7684\u5206\u88c2\u53ca\u6210\u9577\u3002\n\uff08\u4e03\uff09\u690d\u7269\u985e\u96cc\u6fc0\u7d20\u4e4b\u62ee\u6297\u4f5c\u7528: \u5177\u6709\u6e1b\u4f4e\u96c4\u6027\u6216\u96cc\u6027\u6fc0\u7d20\u5c0d\u7d30\u80de\u4e4b\u4f5c\u7528\uff0c\u56e0\u800c\u6291\u5236\u8207\u8377\u723e\u8499\u76f8\u95dc\u4e4b\u764c\u7d30\u80de\u7684\u6210\u9577\u3002\n\uff08\u516b\uff09\u81b3\u98df\u7e96\u7dad\u964d\u4f4e\u8178\u9053\u81f4\u764c\u7269\u5c0d\u4eba\u9ad4\u7684\u5f71\u97ff: \u56e0\u81b3\u98df\u7e96\u7dad\u4e0d\u88ab\u4eba\u9ad4\u6d88\u5316\u5438\u6536\uff0c\u53ef\u589e\u52a0\u7cde\u4fbf\u7684\u9ad4\u7a4d\u53ca\u91cd\u91cf\uff0c\u523a\u6fc0\u8178\u9053\u8815\u52d5\uff0c\u6392\u51fa\u9ad4\u5167\u6bd2\u7d20\uff1b\u540c\u6642\u56e0\u5176\u4e0d\u7522\u751f\u71b1\u91cf\u3001\u5bb9\u6613\u6709\u98fd\u8db3\u611f\uff0c\u6709\u52a9\u9ad4\u91cd\u63a7\u5236\uff0c\u53ef\u6709\u6548\u9810\u9632\u764c\u75c7\u3002\u53e6\u5916\uff0c\u81b3\u98df\u7e96\u7dad\u4ea6\u5177\u6709\u6e1b\u7de9\u98df\u7269\u7684\u6d88\u5316\u5438\u6536\u3001\u964d\u4f4e\u81bd\u56fa\u9187\u5438\u6536\u3001\u6e1b\u4f4e\u8840\u7ba1\u786c\u5316\u6a5f\u7387\u7b49\u529f\u80fd\u3002\n\n\u5e38\u898b\u7684\u690d\u5316\u7d20:\n\uff08\u4e00\uff09\u985e\u9ec3\u916e\u7d20\uff1a(1) \u82b1\u9752\u7d20\u3001\u524d\u82b1\u9752\u7d20\uff1b(2) \u5152\u8336\u7d20\uff1b(3) \u69f2\u76ae\u7d20\uff1b(4) \u6ab8\u6aac\u9ec3\u7d20\uff1b(5) \u82b8\u9999\u7d20\uff1b(6) \u82b9\u83dc\u7d20\u7b49\u3002\n\n\uff08\u4e8c\uff09\u985e\u80e1\u863f\u8514\u7d20\uff1a(1) \u03b2-\u80e1\u863f\u8514\u7d20\u3001\u03b2-\u96b1\u9ec3\u7d20\u3001\u03b1-\u80e1\u863f\u8514\u7d20\uff1b(2) \u8449\u9ec3\u7d20\uff1b(3) \u7389\u7c73\u9ec3\u7d20\uff1b(4) \u8304\u7d05\u7d20\uff1b(5) \u8fa3\u6912\u7d20\u3001\u8fa3\u6912\u7d05\u7d20\u7b49\u3002\n\n\uff08\u4e09\uff09\u6709\u6a5f\u786b\u5316\u7269\uff1a(1) \u863f\u8514\u786b\u7d20\uff1b(3) \u9ea9\u80f1\u7518\u80bd\uff1b(4) \u5432\u54da\uff1b(5) \u7570\u786b\u6c30\u9178\u916f\u7b49\u3002\n\n\uff08\u56db\uff09\u915a\u9178\u985e\uff1a(1) \u7da0\u539f\u9178\uff1b(2) \u97a3\u82b1\u9178\uff1b(3) \u6c92\u98df\u5b50\u9178\uff1b(4) \u5c0d\u9999\u8c46\u9178\uff1b(5) \u963f\u9b4f\u9178\uff1b(6) \u6c34\u694a\u9178\u7b49\u3002\n\n\uff08\u4e94\uff09\u690d\u7269\u96cc\u6fc0\u7d20\uff1a(1) \u7570\u9ec3\u916e\uff1b(2) \u6728\u915a\u7d20\uff1b(3) \u85af\u828b\u7682\u7b49\u3002\n\n\uff08\u516d\uff09\u5176\u4ed6\uff1a(1) \u8449\u7da0\u7d20\uff1b(2) \u8591\u9ec3\u7d20\uff1b(3) \u767d\u85dc\u8606\u9187\uff1b(4) \u5496\u5561\u9178\uff1b(5) \u6ab8\u6aac\u9178\u70ef\u3001\u6ab8\u6aac\u82e6\u7d20\uff1b(6) \u690d\u7269\u7682\u7d20\uff1b(7) \u82e6\u74dc\u82f7\uff1b(8) \u8ff7\u8fed\u9999\u9178\u7b49\u3002\n\n\u4e8b\u5be6\u4e0a\uff0c\u690d\u5316\u7d20\u5c31\u662f\u8b93\u81ea\u5df1\u7684\u9910\u684c\u8b8a\u6210\u300c\u5f69\u8679\u300d\uff0c\u6bcf\u4e00\u5929\u651d\u53d6\u4e0d\u540c\u984f\u8272\u7684\u8c46\u3001\u6996\u3001\u852c\u3001\u679c\uff0c\u6bcf\u4e00\u5929\u5b89\u639230\u5206\u9418\u51fa\u9580\u66ec\u592a\u967d\uff0c\u5b89\u639240\u5206\u9418\u505a\u6709\u6c27\u4ee5\u53ca\u4f38\u5c55\u904b\u52d5\u3002\u4eba\u751f\u5c07\u7531\u300c\u9ed1\u767d\u300d\u671d\u5411\u300c\u5f69\u8679\u300d\u767c\u5c55\u3002\n\n\u795d\u9858\u5927\u5bb6\u5e73\u5b89\u5065\u5eb7\uff0c\u9806\u5fc3\u5409\u7965\uff0c\u8af8\u4e8b\u5713\u6eff\uff0c\u963f\u5f4c\u9640\u4f5b\n\n\u53c3\u8003\u8cc7\u6599\n1. \u98df\u7642\u8056\u7d93: \u6700\u65b0\u79d1\u5b78\u5be6\u8b49\u7528\u5168\u98df\u7269\u852c\u98df\u9006\u8f4915\u5927\u81f4\u6b7b\u75be\u75c5\n\u4f5c\u8005: Yancy, MD, Vice Dean, Diversity and Inclusion; Magerstadt Professor of Medicine; Professor of Medical Social Sciences; \nChief of Cardiology, Department of Medicine; Northwestern University, Feinberg School of Medicine\n\n\nFailure Congestive Heart Failure Australia Cardiac Contractility Modulation\n\nAustralian Medical Supply Company - Life Systems Medical is supplying a new Heart Failure Device called the Optimizer which is designed to improve the condition of Heart Failure patients in Australia.\n\n\n Heart failure is a chronic disease requiring lifelong management. Some forms of heart failure are treated with drugs or with implanted devices such as pacemakers and implantable cardiac defibrillators. However, these treatments are not suitable for all patients and do not always result in an improvement of symptoms. The Optimizer IVs System with CCM technology has been developed to help ease the symptoms in most patients where other treatments are either not applicable or have proven to be minimally effective\nwww.lifesystems.com.au phone 03 925 5888", "channelTitle": "Life Systems Medical Australia", "tags": ["heart failure", "heart", "faiure", "hart", "hart fail", "heart faylure", "congestive heart failure", "congestive", "heartfaulure", "implantable heart", "heart help", "new device", "cardiologist", "cardiology", "heart failure treatment", "heart failure in australia", "australian patients with heart failure", "congestive heart failure in australia", "congestive heart failure treatment", "what to do if you have heart failure"], "publishedAt": "2018-07-11T05:30:02Z", "channelId": "UCmW_ZEqnpLh3Yme8dMkWr1g", "title": "Heart Failure Care in 2018  still a work in progress  Dr Yancy Northwestern University Feinberg"}, "id": "rG-OypbhK24", "statistics": {"commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "126", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "likeCount": "2"}}]}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.11.025", "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.11.025", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1M32S"}, "snippet": {"description": "Tourism Management Perspectives January 2018 Special Issue: Top Tourism Thoughts - https://www.sciencedirect.com/journal/tourism-management-perspectives/vol/25/suppl/C\n\n\nResearch on hospitality and tourism education: Now and future\nHyun Jeong Kim & Miyoung Jeong\n\nAbstract: The education-related topics that have been favored by hospitality and tourism scholars in recent years are presented in this opinion paper. We categorized them into six groups: leadership and human capital development, teaching methods with the emphasis on active and experiential learning, online education, diversity education, internationalization, and industry experience. In addition, we shared our thoughts on additional research topics, reflecting the emerging trends in the hospitality and tourism industry as well as hospitality and tourism academia. Specifically, those thoughts include the development of undergraduate students' cultural competency, issues on hospitality and tourism PhD programs, full-fledged online curricula, and relationships with alumni and advisory board. It is our hope that this article provides some insights regarding the current status of hospitality and tourism education, and stirs up interest in education-related research within hospitality and tourism.\n\nAccess: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tmp.2017.11.025", "title": "Tourism Education (Hyun Jeong Kim & Miyoung Jeong, 2018)", "publishedAt": "2018-02-11T06:30:28Z", "channelTitle": "Tourism Management Perspectives", "channelId": "UCOEnHtChguUPw_VAWQWSeBA"}, "id": "f9ZqUSowP_Q", "statistics": {"commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "45", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "likeCount": "1"}}]}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.11.025", "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.11.025", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT14M36S"}, "snippet": {"description": "What is Infertility? When should I seek help? What treatment is available? I share my own infertility story. This is Part A of a two part series.\n\nWhat is infertility?\nInfertility is defined as the inability to conceive a pregnancy after 12 months of unprotected sexual intercourse. It affects about 1 in 6 Australian couples of reproductive age.\nHowever, if as a female you are older than 33 years, when your ability to conceive begins to decrease over time, you should see someone after 6 months of trying to fall pregnant. \n\nWhat causes infertility? \nThere are various causes that can involve the male, female or a combo deal. This could be sperm production, ovulation, female or male reproductive organs or hormonal or immune conditions. \nHow to get pregnant requires:\n\u2022 A woman\u2019s body must release an egg from one of her ovaries. \n\u2022 A man\u2019s sperm must join with the egg along the way (fertilize).\n\u2022 The fertilized egg must go through a fallopian tube toward the uterus. \n\u2022 The fertilized egg must attach to the inside of the uterus (implantation).\nInfertility may result from a problem with any or several of these steps.\n\n\nReferences:\nhttps://www.ivf.com.au/planning-for-pregnancy/what-is-infertility\nhttps://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/infertility/conditioninfo/common\nhttps://www.cdc.gov/reproductivehealth/infertility/index.htm\nLoGiudice, J. Springer, Cham.\nhttps://tinyurl.com/CultureAugmentedReality", "channelTitle": "Professor Dimitrios Buhalis", "tags": ["buhalis", "strategy", "covid", "tourism", "tourisme", "spanish"], "defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "publishedAt": "2020-07-27T16:11:43Z", "channelId": "UC9R8by0roMNwuzEyEfo7Xaw", "title": "Dimitrios Buhalis Tourisme et Nuevos Horizontes 21st July en espa\u00f1ol"}, "id": "RGPCrYkIiT8", "statistics": {"commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "57", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "likeCount": "1"}}]}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.11.011", "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.11.011", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT59S"}, "snippet": {"description": "Tourism Management Perspectives January 2018 Special Issue: Top Tourism Thoughts - https://www.sciencedirect.com/journal/tourism-management-perspectives/vol/25/suppl/C\n\n\nTourism policy and governance: Quo vadis?\nMarion Joppe\n\nAbstract: This is an opinion piece about research into tourism policy and governance to date and where future research should be undertaken. There is much greater need for policy relevant research that is clear about common definitions of terminology, adopts more consistent methodologies in data collection, challenges the dominant pro-growth rhetoric, and is written in a style accessible to policymakers. Researchers have long argued for a more meaningful role for host communities, but in a time of rapidly increasing tourism and the threat of overtourism in many destination \u201chot spots\u201d, it is no longer an option to stifle their voices.\n\nDecisions related to goal-determination and the selection of methods to achieve the goal are referred to as policies. Although the term generally refers to a decision or action, it actually can also be a negative decision or even a non-action/non-decision. Policies are established in any kind of organization, but when we refer to \u201ctourism policy\u201d, we usually mean some form of \u201cpublic policy\u201d which relates specifically to government decisions at any level from local to international. Governance, on the other hand, is how organizations deal with reaching these decisions. So, while governance is a fairly straightforward concept, albeit with many challenges, tourism policy is not, largely because the term \u201cpolicy\u201d is very fuzzy and tourism is a social construct that refers to a specific behavior: that of traveling to and staying in places outside one's usual environment. This behavior is controlled by policies, legislation and regulations written for many other purposes, such as controlling or facilitating the flow of capital and investments, the transportation of passengers and goods, worker rights, safety and security, or environmental protection. And that's where the trouble starts, because really, the appropriate development of tourism is highly dependent on decision-makers who have little regard for or knowledge of, tourism.\n\nAccess: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tmp.2017.11.011", "channelTitle": "Tourism Management Perspectives", "tags": ["Tourism management perspectives", "marion joppe", "tourism policy", "tourism governance"], "publishedAt": "2018-02-11T06:15:32Z", "channelId": "UCOEnHtChguUPw_VAWQWSeBA", "title": "Tourism Policy and Governance (Marion Joppe, 2018)"}, "id": "cbkRhLAOgJw", "statistics": {"commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "377", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "likeCount": "3"}}]}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.11.011", "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.11.011", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT3M4S"}, "snippet": {"description": "Everyone is curious, but not everyone is curious in the same way\n\nwww.instagram.com/everwonderedyt\nwww.twitter.com/everwonderedyt\nwww.patreon.com/everwonderedyt\nwww.facebook.com/everwonderedyt\n\nReferences:\n\n\nKashdan, T., Stiksma, M., Disabato, D., Mcknight, P., Bekier, J., Kaji, J. (2018). The five-dimensional curiosity scale: Capturing the bandwith of curiosity and identifying four unique subgroups of curious people. Journal of Research and Personality. 73, 130-149. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jrp.2017.11.011\n\nKidd, C. & Hayden, B. (2015). The psychology and Neuroscience of curiosity. Neuron Perspective. 88. (3), 449-460. doi: 10.1016/j.neuron.2015.09.010\n\nEver wondered which kind of curious person are you?\n\nA 2018 study found that roughly speaking there are 4 groups of curious people.\n\nFirst is the fascinated group. This group has persons with inquisitive and usually positive mindsets. \n\nThese fascinated persons are social, assertive and want to know more. Because of this it is likely that they have a lot of passions and interests. Also fascinated people usually see life as an adventure, and just so you know, these fascinated persons usually make more money and have more friends and followers on social media.\n\nThe fascinated group is thought to be approximately 28% of the population\n\nAlso representing 28% of the population is the second group, the Problem Solvers group. Problem solvers are hard-working individuals that love to learn while working relentlessly and they feel that every problem should be solved. \n\nProblem solvers prefer to work in well solving problems and seeking information. They are very independent, and usually show less interest in accessing social media and understanding people.\n\nAlso problem solvers usually see life as a mission to uncover something specific in their lives.\n\nThird group is The Empathizers . Empathizers are distinguished by a high level of social curiosity and represent 25% of the general population", "channelTitle": "Ever Wondered", "tags": ["curiosity", "groups of curious people", What's the longest flight of a chicken? What's the oldest known beer recipe? \n\nwww.instagram.com/everwonderedyt\nwww.twitter.com/everwonderedyt\nwww.twitter.com/everwonderedyt\nwww.facebook.com/everwondered\n\nReferences:\n\nKidd, C. & Hayden, B. (2015). The psychology and Neuroscience of curiosity. Neuron Perspective. 88. (3), 449-460. doi: 10.1016/j.neuron.2015.09.010\n\nKashdan, T., Stiksma, M., Disabato, D., Mcknight, P., Bekier, J., Kaji, J. (2018). The five-dimensional curiosity scale: Capturing the bandwith of curiosity and identifying four unique subgroups of curious people. Journal of Research and Personality. 73, 130-149. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jrp.2017.11.011\n\nHsee, C. & Bowen, R. (2016). The Pandora Effect: The Power and Peril of Curiosity. Psychologicl Science. 27 (5), 659-666.\n\nGrossnickle, E. (2016). Disentangling Curiosity: Dimensionality, Definitions, and Distinctions from Interest in Educational Contexts. Educational Psychology Review. 28, 23-60. DOI 10.1007/s10648-014-9294-y\n\nhttp://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/0956797616631733\nhttps://www.scientificamerican.com/article/curiosity-is-not-intrinsically-good/\nhttps://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_beer\nhttps://factualfacts.com/chicken-longest-recorded-flight/\n\nhttps://books.google.com.mx/books?hl=es&lr=&id=aukqDwAAQBAJ&oi=fnd&pg=PP11&dq=perceptual+epistemic+specific+and+diverse+curiosity&ots=OjjNLP14u9&sig=_LbQUm_ylKn9dtgdJDInkyNeavc#v=onepage&q=epistemic&f=false\n\nAnd even though curiosity is not completely understood it has been associated to enhanced learning, willingness to learn new information and academic persistence. Curiosity has even been related to a higher probability of pleasurable and meaningful moments in life\n\nHowever there are four dimensions of curiosity. The first one is perceptual curiosity. Perceptual curiosity is triggered by a novel, surprising or puzzling stimuli. So when you see something odd and you want to take a closer look. Perceptually curious people usually want to experience something new through the senses. \n\n\nFor example the first time you experience snow, and just so you know the first time I experienced snow was when I was 28 years old so I had a lot of perceptual curiosity. Also perceptual curiosity generally diminishes with continued exposure to the same stimuli, for example the time I got bored of the snow within 15 minutes of touching it for the first time.\n\n\nSecond is Epistemic curiosity, which is the desire for new knowledge. Epistemic curiosity is the desire to know \u201cwhy?\u201d or \u201cwhat if?\u201d . This type of curiosity it\u2019s the one that comes to your mind when you think about curious people. And some people even think that epistemic curiosity is one of the main driving forces of scientific research and of philosophical inquiry.\n\nEpistemic curiosity it\u2019s thought to motivate exploratory behavior in non-human animals and perhaps in human infants. \n\nPeople that are epistemically curious believe that a good life is about working to achieve one\u2019s potential and cultivate knowledge", "channelTitle": "Ever Wondered", "tags": ["curiosity", "everwondered", "ever wondered", "why are we curious ever wondered", "why are we curious", "why are we curious everwondered", "curiosity function", "whats the point of curiosity", "curiosity explained"], "publishedAt": "2018-06-05T17:00:01Z", "channelId": "UCpseQ_i-4RUvyC4Bx7R9tpg", "title": "Why are we curious? #everwondered #scicomm"}, "id": "H03jXfGh_Qk", "statistics": {"commentCount": "4", "viewCount": "942", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "3", "likeCount": "33"}}]}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.11.011", "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.11.011", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1H53M33S"}, "snippet": {"description": "On Tourism & Sustainability FREE webinar 17th April 2020\nTourism in a post COVID-19 world: A discussion on a number of important and challenging issues that the tourism industry now faces. https://youtu.be/CcdndqsuqKQ\nOrganised and Chaired by Professor Eugenia Wickens\nDr Wendy Sealy, University of Chichester\nProfessor Dimitrios Buhalis, Bournemouth University \nhttps://youtu.be/CcdndqsuqKQ \n\nFor details see www.ontourism.online\n______________________________________________________\nProfessor Buhalis presentation is based on research articulated on those articles:\nBuhalis, D. This discussion followed the presentation on Digital Marketing by Kyros Asfis and raised a range of questions that will be answered tomorrow\n\n#WeAreTogether is a campaign of 30-minute live shows that broadcast daily on Instagram, on the official channel of @inomodesign at 19:00 pm GMT+2 where business owners and professionals in hospitality and design industry will share with us their stories,experiences,tips and more.\n\nVivian Paraschou who is the owner of INOMO and the initiator of #WeAreTogether started this initiative on 19 of March in order to raise voice against isolation and bring the professionals of the hospitality industry together. To empower them to think postive and spend their time efficiently. In these hard time of crisis that tourism industry and hospitality sector has been affected the most, we decided to take action and empower them to remain active. We are working in detail on each talk in order to give value to our audience, our clients, colleagues and everyone that is operating in the hospitality industry. We all should remain active and support each other sharing tools,tips and case studies.\n\nThe talk reiterates the discussion that Professor Buhalis Bournemouth University has been developing in Rapid We find that incorporating global inflation as a predictor yields significantly more accurate forecasts of local inflation for a diverse group of 14 advanced countries (including the U.S.) than either a simple autoregressive model or a standard closed-economy Phillips curve-based forecasting model. Moreover, we also show that global inflation alone (that is, excluding domestic slack) often contributes the most to achieve the gains on forecasting accuracy observed during our sample period (1984:Q1-2015:Q1).\n\nYou can find out more, reading our paper here: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jedc.2017.11.006", "channelTitle": "emgeconomics", "tags": ["Enrique Martinez-Garcia", "Enrique Fechando nossa trilogia sobre conserva\u00e7\u00e3o, vamos falar sobre algumas refer\u00eancias nos estudos de conserva\u00e7\u00e3o.\n\nAbordamos todos os desafios de se conservar em um pa\u00eds megadiverso! Justin Miron explains how they discovered the CDK5RAP2 gene and the association of variants of this gene with the risk of developing Alzheimer\u2019s disease. There are rare surveys that link these variables with small businesses performance. Combining several dimensions of these variables, this study aimed to verify which strategy configurations composed by the strategy development process, strategy content, entrepreneurial attitude, administrative mode and perceived environmental uncertainty were associated with the performance of small-sized clothing retail businesses. Data collected by survey with 228 companies and investigated by cluster analysis technique revealed two groups/clusters of companies with different configurations and performance levels. The results indicate the relationship of interdependence among variables in explaining the heterogeneity of organizational performance.\n\nhttp://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.rauspm.2017.12.005", of promoting growth and providing immunity in the plant system. Panchagavya consists of nine products viz. cow dung, cow urine, milk, curd, jaggery, ghee, banana, Tender coconut. In this paper, the history and a selection of current trends are reviewed. By focussing the discussion on the changes in universities, processes of publication and tourism itself, the paper highlights some early scholarship which paved the way and shaped current tourism knowledge. The paper concludes by asking the pertinent question of where tourism researchers might be in the future, when they have to cope with the increasing demands of academia today.\n\nAccess: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tmp.2017.12.005", "channelTitle": "Tourism Management Perspectives", "tags": ["tourism management perspectives", "chris ryan", "emerging tourism research"], "publishedAt": "2018-02-11T06:13:38Z", "channelId": "UCOEnHtChguUPw_VAWQWSeBA", "title": "Emerging Tourism Research (Chris Ryan, 2018)"}, "id": "2Lu2GAdY6ws", "statistics": {"commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "525", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "likeCount": "1"}}]}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.12.005", "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.12.005", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT3M36S"}, "snippet": {"description": "Medicine by Alexandros G. Sfakianakis,Anapafseos 5 Agios Nikolaos 72100 Crete Greece,00302841026182,00306932607174,alsfakia@gmail.com,\r\nhttps://plus.google.com/communities/115462130054650919641?sqinv=VFJWaER0c2NCRl9ERzRjZWhxQmhzY09kVV84cjRn\r\n,\r\n,https://plus.google.com/u/0/+AlexandrosGSfakianakis\r\n,\r\nhttps://www.youtube.com/channel/UCQH21WX8Qn5YSTKrlJ3OrmQ\r\n,\r\nhttps://www.youtube.com/channel/UCTREJHxB6yt4Gaqs4-mLzDA\r\n,\r\nhttps://twitter.com/g_orl?lang=el,\r\nhttps://www.instagram.com/alexandrossfakianakis/,\r\n\r\nA retrospective study of treatment for curative synchronous double primary cancers of the head and neck and the esophagus.\r\nScience.gov (United States)\r\nOkamoto, Tabito; Katada, Chikatoshi; Komori, Shouko; Yamashita, Keishi; Miyamoto, Shunsuke; Kano, Koichi; Seino, Yutomo; Hosono, Hiroshi; Matsuba, Hiroki; Moriya, Hiromitsu; Sugawara, Mitsuhiro; Azuma, Mizutomo; Ishiyama, Hiromichi; Tanabe, Satoshi; Hayakawa, Kazushige; Koizumi, Wasaburo; Okamoto, Makito; Yamashita, Taku\r\n2018-05-08  PubMed\r\nDOI: 10.1016/j.anl.2017.12.005  ISSN: 0385-8146\r\nKeywords: Esophageal cancer, Head and neck cancer, Induction chemotherapy, Synchronous double primary cancers, TPF chemotherapy\r\nCurative synchronous double primary cancers of the head and neck and the esophagus (CSC-HE) are frequently detected, but a standard treatment remains to be established. We studied the clinical course to explore appropriate treatment strategies. We retrospectively studied consecutive 33 patients who had CSC-HE. The disease stage was classified into 4 groups: group A, early head and neck cancer (HNC) and early esophageal cancer (EC); group B, early HNC and advanced EC; group C, advanced HNC and early EC; and group D, advanced HNC and advanced EC. As induction chemotherapy, the patients received 3 courses of TPF therapy (docetaxel 75mg/m 2 on day 1, cisplatin 75mg/m 2 on day 1, and 5-fluorouracil 750mg/m 2 on days 1-5) at 3-week intervals. The clinical courses and treatment outcomes were studied according to the disease stage of CSC-HE. The disease stage of CSC-HE was group A in 1 patient (3%), group B in 9 patients (27.3%), group C in 3 patients (9.1%), and group D in 20 patients (60.6%). The median follow-up was 26months, and the 2-year overall survival rate was 67.4%. In groups A, B, and C, the 2-year overall survival rate was 83.3%. In group D, the 2-year overall survival rate was 62.6%. Ten of 20 patients in group D received induction chemotherapy with TPF, and 6 patients were alive and disease free at the time of this writing. The treatment outcomes of patients with CSC-HE were relatively good. TPF induction chemotherapy might be an effective treatment for patients with advanced HNC and advanced EC. Copyright \u00a9 2018. https://www.sciencedirect.com/journal/tourism-management-perspectives/vol/25/suppl/C\n\n\nFuture of hospitality marketing and management research\nDogan Gursoy\n\nAbstract: Over the past few decades, research focus in hospitality marketing and management has been shifting from product development approach to understanding consumer product evaluation in the purchase decision and the factors that are likely to influence customers' decision making process. As the field experiences maturity and scientific sophistication, it is important for hospitality marketing and management researchers to fully understand the breadth and depth of existing knowledge, the stages of development the field have experienced in the past few decades and the future of hospitality marketing and management research. Therefore, this short opinion piece aims to provide a brief overview of development of the hospitality marketing and management research throughout the last few decades and then discuss some of the topics that might be examined/studied by hospitality marketing and management researchers in the near future.\n\nAccess: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tmp.2017.11.008", "channelTitle": "Tourism Management Perspectives", "tags": ["tourism management perspectives", "dogan gursoy", "hospitality management"], "publishedAt": "2018-02-11T06:19:40Z", "channelId": "UCOEnHtChguUPw_VAWQWSeBA", "title": "Hospitality Management (Dogan Gursoy, 2018)"}, "id": "_WwbfL93FgQ", "statistics": {"commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "94", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "likeCount": "1"}}]}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.11.008", "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.11.008", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT58S"}, "snippet": {"description": "This video is associated with the article:\nNencioli, F., Dall\u2019Olmo, G., & Quartly, G. D. (2018). Agulhas ring transport efficiency from combined satellite altimetry and Argo profiles. Journal of Geophysical Research: Oceans, 123, 5874\u20135888.\nhttps://doi.org/10.1029/2018JC013909\n\nDESCRIPTION:\nLagrangian particles were deployed at regular interval within the 3 eddies shown in https://youtu.be/cq9qu0hmmSI and advected for 6 months after each deployment. \n\nInitially there is a large number of particles lost by the eddies, and the particles tend to rapidly disperse away from the eddies. After the eddies cross the Walvis Ridge (between 0 and 5E), the number of particles retained increases and the ones that are lost tend to follow the westward movement of the eddies. When the third eddy dissipates in front of the Brasilian coast the particles rapidly disperse to the north and to the south-west following the coastline.\n\nAs in https://youtu.be/hak7D_WWG6E, the velocity fields used to advect the particles are available at the Copernicus Marine Environment Monitoring Service (CMEMS) website:\nhttp://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=SEALEVEL_GLO_PHY_L4_REP_OBSERVATIONS_008_047\n\nLagrangian particles have been advected using the LAMTA code described in Van Sebille et al. 2018 (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ocemod.2017.11.008).", "title": "Particle advection within three eddies in the South Atlantic Ocean", "publishedAt": "2018-02-02T17:33:54Z", "channelTitle": "Francesco Nencioli", "channelId": "UCe8cp7BvM1cMnA5dwNSVQ3g"}, "id": "_WkTloTrxUQ", "statistics": {"commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "120", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "likeCount": "1"}}]}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.11.008", "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.11.008", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1M9S"}, "snippet": {"description": "Dr. Francesco Spagnolo \nFacebook: https://www.facebook.com/francesco.spagnolo.1232\nIstangram: https://www.instagram.com/spagnolo_francesco_ph/?hl=it\nLinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/francesco-spagnolo-3416b474/\n___________________________________________________________________________\nTensegrity and Biotensegrity are an old concept. Journal of Geophysical Research: Oceans, 123, 5874\u20135888.\nhttps://doi.org/10.1029/2018JC013909\n\nDESCRIPTION:\nIn https://youtu.be/cq9qu0hmmSI, we showed that two Agulhas eddies merged after the Mid Atlantic Ridge (~15W) to form a new mesoscale eddy. This video shows the different contributions of the two eddies to its formation.\n\nLagrangian particles were released within the newly formed eddy and then advected backward in time for 6 months. The path to printing an organ is far from easy though and many problems have to be solved with regards to bioprinters, bioinks and capillary formation in the organ. \n\nA big thanks to the Wake Forest Institure for Renegerative medicine and Dr. Anthony Atala for the footage and images on the bioprinting process:\nhttps://school.wakehealth.edu/Research/Institutes-and-Centers/Wake-Forest-Institute-for-Regenerative-Medicine\n\nThe Wake Forest Institute for Regenerative Medicine is recognized as an international leader in translating scientific discovery into clinical therapies, with many world firsts, including the development and implantation of the first engineered organ in a patient. More than 450 scientists collaborate on regenerative medicine research at the institute, the largest in the world, working on more than 40 different tissues and organs. The institute is part of Wake Forest University and is located in the Innovation Quarter in downtown Winston-Salem, NC. Through partnerships and collaborations with many regenerative medicine centers internationally, the institute, which is driven by the urgent needs of patients, is making a global difference in the world of regenerative medicine.\n\nResources \n\nMagazine stories etc. on bioprinters: \n\nAn interesting Guardian article on bioprinting and bioprinting startups:\nhttps://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/jul/30/will-3d-printing-solve-the-organ-transplant-shortage\n\nA conversation with Dr. Stephanie Willerth, a researcher in biomedical engineering, about the state of bioprinting and the implications of the technology. https://www.3dprintingmedia.network/lets-get-real-what-can-we-bioprint-and-what-is-just-media-hype/\n\nShorter blog posts on 3D bioprinting in general:\nhttps://www.lifecyclebio.com/2018/07/27/3d-bioprinting-the-state-of-the-art-in-regenerative-medicine/\nhttps://www.sculpteo.com/blog/2018/02/21/3d-bioprinting-what-can-we-achieve-today-with-a-3d-bioprinter/\nhttps://all3dp.com/brief-introduction-3d-bioprinting/\n\nAn overview of the different 3D bioprinting companies \nhttps://medicalfuturist.com/top-bioprinting-companies\n\n--\n\nOther articles and resources\n\nThe global market for 3D bioprinting is estimated to reach 1 billion dollars by the early 2020's \nhttps://blog.marketresearch.com/3d-bioprinting-a-revolutionary-technology-in-the-healthcare-industry\n\nA review article on the integrated tissue organ printer and on the ear construct printed with it at the Wake Forest Institute for Regenerative Medicine:\nhttps://doi.org/10.1038/nbt.3413\n\nA review article on the different approaches to bioinks:\nhttps://doi.org/10.1557/mrs.2017.164\n\nOPEN ACCESS - A thorough article on different 3D bioprinting methods and bioinks\nhttps://doi.org/10.1016/j.bioactmat.2017.11.008\n\nAnother very thorough review article focusing on the different tissue types being printed. These abilities form the basis for many traits that would seem uniquely human, such as using language and enjoying music. I will explore whether and to what extent such abilities may also be present in birds and what this may tell about how the cognitive abilities of bird species relate to those of humans.\n\nMichelle J. Shifts in modes of governance are described, along with some key concerns related to mobilities and hyper-neoliberism. The paper raises the question of what constitutes good governance in the context of good tourism (e.g., sustainable tourism, responsible tourism, pro-poor tourism). Drawing on case research as well as theoretical influences, it forwards for future consideration justice as a key principle for good governance and policy in tourism. The importance of cultural values, and of addressing the historical context are noted. The Critical Opinion also calls on researchers to engage with diverse theoretical perspectives and research methodologies that can help facilitate \u201cjust governance\u201d to tourism.\n\nAccess: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tmp.2017.11.009", "channelTitle": "Tourism Management Perspectives", "tags": ["tourism management perspectives", "tourism policy", "tourism governance", "tazim jamal", "bianca camargo"], "publishedAt": "2018-02-11T06:17:49Z", "channelId": "UCOEnHtChguUPw_VAWQWSeBA", "title": "Tourism Policy and Governance (Tazim Jamal & Bianca Camargo, 2018)"}, "id": "YCAZ9IH15Kw", "statistics": {"commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "281", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "likeCount": "2"}}]}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.11.009", "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.11.009", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT10M1S"}, "snippet": {"description": "\u3010\u30af\u30ed\u30b9\u30c1\u30e3\u30f3\u30cd\u30eb\u6708\u984d995\u5186\u3011\nhttps://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_s-xclick&hosted_button_id=KXJHQ7EK38KQ4\n\nGignac, G. vehicles to incorporate solar charging along with the potential issues that have to be overcome first.\n\nIt concludes by saying that whilst our next electric cars will not be entirely solar powered but the work being carried out in the Australian outback, and by engineers around the world, is starting to prove that although a solar powered car isn't feasible, a practical, solar assisted EV is, [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1M45S"}, "snippet": {"description": "Tourism Management Perspectives January 2018 Special Issue: Top Tourism Thoughts - https://www.sciencedirect.com/journal/tourism-management-perspectives/vol/25/suppl/C\n\nSustainable tourism: Sustaining tourism or something more?\nFreya Higgins-Desbiolles\n\nAbstract: Tourism today has a problem. It is addicted to growth, which is incompatible with sustainability goals. Despite three decades discussing pathways to sustainable tourism, tourism authorities continue to promote tourism growth despite the ecological and social limits of living on a finite planet. This article argues that tourism must be understood and managed with a wider context of sustainability. Additionally, strategic approaches to transitioning to a sufficiency approach to tourism and leisure is essential if sustainability is to be secured. Recommendations include: transforming the United Nations World Tourism Organization into an Office for Sustainable Mobilities, creating a global Tourism Wealth Fund, fostering diverse approaches to tourism strategies for development and regulating and managing tourism for a better balanced accounting for fairness, ecological limits, human benefit and sustainable futures. The growth fetish is resulting in tourism killing tourism. An approach focused on sustaining tourism is not a sustainable form of tourism.\n\nAccess: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tmp.2017.11.017", "channelTitle": "Tourism Management Perspectives", "tags": ["Sustainable Tourism Development", "Freya Higgins-Desbiolles", "Tourism Management Perspectives"], "publishedAt": "2018-02-11T06:09:01Z", "channelId": "UCOEnHtChguUPw_VAWQWSeBA", "title": "Sustainable Tourism Development (Freya Higgins-Desbiolles, 2018)"}, "id": "6ujlNHnwrYE", "statistics": {"commentCount": "5", "viewCount": "575", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "likeCount": "8"}}]}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.11.017", "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.11.017", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT2M11S"}, "snippet": {"description": "Medicine by Alexandros G. Sfakianakis,Anapafseos 5 Agios Nikolaos 72100 Crete Greece,00302841026182,00306932607174,alsfakia@gmail.com,\r\nhttps://plus.google.com/communities/115462130054650919641?sqinv=VFJWaER0c2NCRl9ERzRjZWhxQmhzY09kVV84cjRn\r\n,\r\n,https://plus.google.com/u/0/+AlexandrosGSfakianakis\r\n,\r\nhttps://www.youtube.com/channel/UCQH21WX8Qn5YSTKrlJ3OrmQ\r\n,\r\nhttps://www.youtube.com/channel/UCTREJHxB6yt4Gaqs4-mLzDA\r\n,\r\nhttps://twitter.com/g_orl?lang=el,\r\nhttps://www.instagram.com/alexandrossfakianakis/,\r\n\r\n\r\nArticle in Press\r\nHow Age and Frequency Impact the Thyroid Cartilages of Professional Singers\r\nFabian Unteregger, Jan Thommen, Flurin Honegger, Silke Potthast, Salome Zwicky, Claudio Storck'Correspondence information about the author Claudio StorckEmail the author Claudio Storck\r\nDOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jvoice.2017.11.017\r\nshowArticle Info\r\nAbstract\r\nFull Text\r\nImages\r\nReferences\r\nSummary\r\nObjectives/Hypothesis\r\nYoung professional singers can easily reach very high pitches. In contrast, older singers often complain that they have to exert substantially more laryngopharyngeal force to reach the same high pitch compared with their earlier years. Various factors such as the property changes of the mucosa and ossification that impact the singing apparatus were suggested as explanations in the literature. The aim of this study was to analyze thyroid deformation\u2014and thereby stiffness indirectly\u2014during singing as a potential reason for this phenomenon.\r\n\r\nStudy Design\r\nProspective study.\r\n\r\nMethods/design\r\nWe examined 44 female professional singers. High-resolution computed tomography scans were performed during singing at the fundamental mean speaking frequency and the first and second octaves above it. Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine scan data were rendered and visualized 3-dimensionally using MIMICS software. By superimposition of the different 3-dimensional images, different positions of the thyroid were visualized. The distance from the posterior border of the thyroid was measured in all the examinations.\r\n\r\nResults\r\nAll laryngeal cartilages could be three-dimensionally visualized. The magnitude of the thyroidal deformation significantly depends on pitch and significantly correlates with age (r2\u2009=\u20090.7, P\u2009\u20090.001).\r\n\r\nConclusions\r\nThe thyroid cartilage is flexible and its formability is especially important during singing. At higher pitches, the cartilage was more deformed. The larynx in older singers showed less thyroid cartilage deformation.\r\n\r\nKey Words:\r\nLarynx, Singer, Laryngeal cartilage, Deformation, Aging\n\r\n\r- video upload powered by https://www.TunesToTube.com", "channelTitle": "Alexandros G. Sfakianakis", "tags": ["Larynx", "Singer", "Laryngeal", "cartilage", "Deformation", "Aging"], "publishedAt": "2018-01-16T06:28:45Z", "channelId": "UCTREJHxB6yt4Gaqs4-mLzDA", "title": "The thyroid cartilage is flexible and its formability is especially important during singing"}, "id": "7bDF2wyVGUk", "statistics": {"commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "22", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "likeCount": "0"}}]}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.11.017", "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.11.017", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT50M33S"}, "snippet": {"description": "Martes 18 de septiembre           \nTema del d\u00eda: Impactos del cambio clim\u00e1tico en M\u00e9xico\n\nDiagn\u00f3stico y propuesta sobre la correlaci\u00f3n entre variabilidad clim\u00e1tica,  calidad del aire y sus impactos en la salud\n\nPonentes:\nDr. Horacio Riojas Rodr\u00edguez, Director de Salud Ambiental del Instituto Nacional de Salud P\u00fablica.\nDr.  Luis Gerardo Ruiz Su\u00e1rez, Centro de Ciencias de la Atm\u00f3sfera, UNAM.", "defaultLanguage": "es-419", "channelTitle": "INECC SEMARNAT", "tags": ["INECC", "MIDE", "SEMARNAT", "CAMBIO CLIM\u00c1TICO", "MEXICO", "CONFERENCIAS", "TERCER ENCUENTRO"], "publishedAt": "2018-10-15T21:11:15Z", "channelId": "UC2Z8f7gE0HTsL6sxguPz90Q", "title": "Calidad del aire, salud y cambio clim\u00e1tico"}, "id": "tmZPmFv_3W4", "statistics": {"commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "36", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "likeCount": "0"}}]}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.11.018", "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.11.018", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT2M13S"}, "snippet": {"description": "Tourism Management Perspectives January 2018 Special Issue: Top Tourism Thoughts - https://www.sciencedirect.com/journal/tourism-management-perspectives/vol/25/suppl/C\n\nTourism as a heritage producing machine\nMaria Gravari-Barbas\n\nAbstract: The purpose of this document is to analyze the role that tourism has historically played and still plays today in the emergence and affirmation of the modern concept of heritage. It particularly looks to highlight the operational co-production of heritage and tourism and shows that tourism has never worked better, faster and more efficiently as a heritage-producing machine than in this beginning of the 21st century. We are on the threshold of a new \u201cheritage regime\u201d, which presents a gap compared with the one that produced the major European national heritages in the State-Nations of the 19th century. The tourism system (tourism actors, places and businesses as well as tourists themselves) contribute to the production of a new heritage system (heritage places, practices and actors) which functions according to its own needs and expectations, in a world of free traffic, transactions and generalized mobilities.\n\nAccess: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tmp.2018.01.004\n\n--\n\nMaking sense of heritage tourism: Research trends in a maturing field of study\nDallen Timothy\n\nAbstract: This essay examines several emerging research trends in the field of heritage tourism. These trends, including experiential connections with heritage, blurred boundaries between tourisms, more accurate portrayals of the commodified past and technological advancements, demonstrate a precipitous growth in heritage tourism scholarship that focuses more on experience, identity, stewardship, place and empowerment than the more descriptive supply v. demand work that preceded it. Changes in how researchers treat the cultural past indicate a maturing field of study that is increasing in popularity as a focus of academic research and also as a consumable tourist product.\n\nAccess: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tmp.2017.11.018", "title": "Heritage Tourism (Maria Gravari-Barbas / Dallen Timothy, 2018)", "publishedAt": "2018-02-11T06:22:52Z", "channelTitle": "Tourism Management Perspectives", "channelId": "UCOEnHtChguUPw_VAWQWSeBA"}, "id": "Bl42bdpHVMo", "statistics": {"commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "150", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "likeCount": "1"}}]}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.11.018", "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.11.018", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT15M8S"}, "snippet": {"description": "Improving Spatially Distributed Travel Time Methods for Hydrograph Prediction by Better Accounting for Upstream Flow Contributions\n\nSpatially distributed travel time (SDTT) methods have been proposed as an alternative between lumped unit hydrographs and fully distributed hydraulic routing methods in rainfall-runoff modeling. SDTT methods transform a basin\u2019s runoff into stormflow at the outlet by calculating the flood wave travel time within each cell of a digital elevation model and then summing the travel times from each cell to the outlet. A controversial aspect of SDTT methods is that they approximate the upstream flow contributions when calculating the flood wave travel time in each cell. In reality, the upstream contribution varies with time and space in a watershed, which alters the travel times of the flood wave. SDTT methods either assume all upstream areas simultaneously contribute flow to a point, a static portion of upstream areas contribute, or no upstream contributions occur. Assuming full upstream contributions usually overestimates travel times, while neglecting upstream contributions underestimates travel times. Thus, a key question is how should the partial contribution of upstream areas be estimated? In this study, two approaches are considered: a fraction approach that assumes a constant fraction of the upstream area contributes flow and a power approach that estimates the upstream contribution using a power function. These methods are applied to multiple synthetic basins with different geomorphic characteristics (e.g., uplift rate, material erodibility, etc.). For each basin, four storm hyetographs and three different average intensities for each hyetograph are applied. A fully distributed kinematic wave model is used as a benchmark to assess the performance of the methods for each case. Results show that the fraction and power value can change with the basin characteristics, storm duration, and storm intensity. However, the fraction value usually remains within a narrower range than the power value. Thus, the fraction approach provides a better approximation when applying SDTT methods.", "channelTitle": "One Water Solutions Institute", "tags": ["OWSI", "One Water Solutions Insitute", "Colorado State University", "AGU Hydrology Days", "Civil and Environmental Engineering", "Hydrologic Systems"], "publishedAt": "2020-05-12T15:19:04Z", "channelId": "UC7nNrIUznXii6_u0axbhQrA", "title": "Meshal Alothman - Hydrologic Systems Session AGU Hydrology Days"}, "id": "bawUpjEajXs", "statistics": {"commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "13", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "likeCount": "0"}}]}, "snippet": {"description": "In the Rock Physic laboratory at the NOC, we have designed an experimental multi-flow rig for CO2 storage experiments that allow us to relate geophysical signatures of rocks samples to their hydro-mechanical changes, under controlled thermal and pressure conditions. In a common 2-phase flow experiment, we inject CO2 and brine in a rock sample. We can measure strains and relative permeability in continuous, while resistivity and ultrasonic properties can be acquired at any time (see https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijggc.2017.11.019).", "title": "High Pressure Multi-flow Experimental Rig at the NOC", "publishedAt": "2018-01-26T15:45:22Z", "channelTitle": "Ismael Falcon", "channelId": "UCZc-OFbzsGxym5qnqhjuhsA"}, "id": "KLkdwXXFc4c", "statistics": {"commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "155", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "likeCount": "2"}}]}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.11.019", "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.11.019", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT12M33S"}, "snippet": {"description": "Bilaterians, the kind of creature we are most familiar with, have dominated the Animal Kingdom for well over half a billion years. But for tens of millions of years, they were just an odd collection of tiny bottom feeders. However, once bilateral symmetry evolved, it was poised and ready to seize the stage. This moment in time is known as \u201cthe Cambrian Explosion\u201d.  But how exactly did bilaterians manage to take over in the end? What kickstarted the Cambrian Explosion and can we expect the same thing to happen in alien biospheres? Was the Cambrian Explosion destined to happen or just a fortunate fluke? Would bilaterally symmetrical animals always evolve on Earth-like worlds? The corresponding structures were characterized by X-ray diffraction and Rietveld refinement techniques, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, ultraviolet\u2013visible absorption spectroscopy, and photoluminescence measurements. Field emission scanning electron microscopy was used to investigate the morphology of the as-synthesized aggregates. The structure, the surface stability of the (001), (112), (100), (110), (101), and (111) surfaces of CaMoO4, and their morphological transformations were investigated through systematic first-principles calculations within the density functional theory method at the B3LYP level. Analysis of the surface structures showed that the electronic properties were associated with the presence of undercoordinated [CaOx] (x = 5 and 6) and [MoOy] (y = 4 and 3) clusters. The relative surfaces energies were tuned to predict a complete map of the morphologies available through a Wulff construction approach. The results reveal that the experimental and theoretical morphologies obtained coincide when the surface energies of the (001) and (101) surfaces increase, while the surface energy of the (100) facet decreases simultaneously. The results provide a comprehensive catalog of the morphologies most likely to be present under realistic conditions, and will serve as a starting point for future studies on the surface chemistry of CaMoO4 crystals.\n\nAuthors: F. K. F. Oliveira, M. C.Oliveira, L. Gracia, R. L.Tranquilina, C. A. Paskocimas, F. V. Motta, E. Longo, J.Andr\u00e9s, M. R. D. Journal of Nursing Management,26(5), 555-562. doi:10.1111/jonm.12582", "title": "Teamwork Makes the Dream Work", "publishedAt": "2018-10-28T21:33:57Z", "channelTitle": "Margret Miller", "channelId": "UCTdFBhb8-xsyg66ymKFl0JQ"}, "id": "CiIv4wUv9A0", "statistics": {"commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "161", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "likeCount": "0"}}]}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.11.023", "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.11.023", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1M10S"}, "snippet": {"description": "Tourism Management Perspectives January 2018 Special Issue: Top Tourism Thoughts - https://www.sciencedirect.com/journal/tourism-management-perspectives/vol/25/suppl/C\n\n\nNew technologies in tourism: From multi-disciplinary to anti-disciplinary advances and trajectories\nMarianna Sigala\n\nAbstract: Technologies transform tourism management and marketing from a static and utilitarian sense (whereby managers and tourists use technologies as tools) to a transformative conceptualization whereby tourism markets and actors both shape and are shaped by technology. This paper unravels the transformative power of technologies on: the tourism actors and resources (both the traditional but also new actors, i.e. the technology agents); the ways actors interact to (co-)create but also (co-)destruct tourism value; and the context in which tourism actors interact from a linear supply chain tourism \u2018industry\u2019 to a complex socio-technical smart tourism ecosystem. To study such complex phenomena and transformations, the paper emphasises that research should not only adopt a multi-disciplinary approach, but it also needs to follow an anti-disciplinary thinking whereby new knowledge and constructs do not simply fall within existing paradigms, disciplinary silos and mindsets once developed by studying the \u2018pure\u2019 humans and their behaviours.\n\nAccess: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tmp.2017.12.003\n\n--\n\nFrom digitization to the age of acceleration: On information technology and tourism\nPhil Xiang\n\nAbstract: This essay presents an overview of the research development over the last twenty years on information technology and tourism. It argues that knowledge created in the last two decades can be characterized as consisting of two distinct eras, i.e., Digitization (1997\u20132006) and Age of Acceleration (2007\u20132016), which reflected the general understanding of how technology has transformed our society and economy. Knowledge development within each of these eras is examined in terms of the technological conditions, dominant paradigms, main research questions, and influential discipline and research approaches. Particularly, it recognizes the shift of our view of information technology in tourism research from a primarily a marketing-driven tool to a knowledge creation tool due to new technological conditions such as the smartphone, drone, wearables, new connectivity and big data. Finally, this essay discusses possible future research problems and challenges our existing views of the relationship between information technology and tourism.\n\nAccess: https://www.edx.org/course/pivoting-to-online-teaching-research-and-practitioner-perspectives - https://linkresearchlab.org/pivot/", "channelTitle": "LINK Lab", "tags": ["Online Teaching", "Online Learning"], "defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "publishedAt": "2020-03-29T00:54:46Z", "channelId": "UCxEG3cLOmcPJaxvJLF1dbew", "title": "Week 1 - Live Session"}, "id": "sVCaoulGsDY", "statistics": {"viewCount": "223", "favoriteCount": "0"}}]}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.11.042", "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.11.042", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1M51S"}, "snippet": {"description": "Papers and Questionnaires (see supplementary material)\nLong form: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/313968844_Supplementary_material\nYlenio Longo, Iain Coyne, Stephen Joseph,\nThe scales of general well-being (SGWB),\nPersonality and Individual Differences,\nVolume 109,\n2017,\nPages 148-159,\nISSN 0191-8869,\nhttps://doi.org/10.1016/j.paid.2017.01.005.\n(http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0191886917300065)\nAbstract: This paper presents the development and validation of a new well-being questionnaire: the Scales of General Well-Being (SGWB). A review of current measures identified fourteen common constructs as lower-order indicators of well-being: happiness, vitality, calmness, optimism, involvement, self-awareness, self-acceptance, self-worth, competence, development, purpose, significance, self-congruence and connection. Three studies were then conducted. In study 1, the item pool was developed and the adequacy of its content to assess each of the fourteen constructs was evaluated by consulting a panel of six subject expert academics. In study 2, the dimensionality was assessed in an adult North American sample (N=560). The results supported the hierarchical factor structure. In study 3, further evidence confirmed the factor structure, and provided support for the measure's internal and test-retest reliability, measurement invariance across gender, age and a longitudinal period of 5weeks, and criterion validity in an adult North American sample (N=1101). The SGWB promises to be a useful research tool that provides both a global measure of well-being as well as a collection of fourteen individual health-related scales.\nKeywords: Scale development; Scale validation; Bifactor; Higher-order; Well-being; Measurement; Quality of life\n\nShort form: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/327102158_14-item_Scales_of_General_Well-Being_14-SGWB \nYlenio Longo, Iain Coyne, Stephen Joseph,\nDevelopment of the short version of the Scales of General Well-Being: The 14-item SGWB,\nPersonality and Individual Differences,\nVolume 124,\n2018,\nPages 31-34,\nISSN 0191-8869,\nhttps://doi.org/10.1016/j.paid.2017.11.042.\n(http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0191886917306992)\nAbstract: The Scales of General Well-Being (SGWB, Longo, Coyne, & Joseph, 2017) is a 65-item tool assessing fourteen different constructs. The aim of this study was to develop a short 14-item version. One item was chosen from each of the fourteen scales following inspection of previously-published factor loadings and content validity ratings. In total, 446 responses from U.S residents were collected from Amazon Mechanical Turk. Results supported a factor structure consistent with the long form, as well as good internal consistency. Additionally, general well-being scores of short- and long-form correlated at 0.96 and each item in the short-form was strongly related to its respective long-form scale. The 14-item SGWB offers a brief assessment of well-being based on a novel and comprehensive operational definition, and promises to be of practical use to researchers and clinicians.\nKeywords: Well-being; Short form; SGWB; Flourishing; Measurement; Scale; Validation; Factor analysis\n\nIntroductory donde Ana Merenciano nos presenta un ejemplo de inteligencia animal con rapaces australianas que se dedican a expandir fuego.\n- Mala Ciencia - donde comentamos la retractaci\u00f3n de un art\u00edculo cient\u00edfico de la revista Science sobre el efecto de los micropl\u00e1sticos en larvas de peces.\n- Geoviajes - os invitamos a visitar Penyagolosa, una de las monta\u00f1as m\u00e1s emblem\u00e1ticas de la Comunidad Valenciana.\n- Planetolog\u00eda - donde os hablamos de los puntos de Lagrange en las \u00f3rbitas de los planetas y los Asteroides Troyanos que en ellos se sit\u00faan.\n\nEste v\u00eddeo se ofrece bajo la licencia Creative Commons de Youtube pero contiene contenido protegido por copyright de Zemia Media SL, ESA TV, Videoblocks, Neurodrome, Science Magazine, Google, Elsevier, The University of Uppsala, The University of Texas in Austin, Bob Gosford, Sveriges Radio, Google, Nobel Media y Manel Alemany Mart\u00ednez.\n\nAdem\u00e1s, incluye el siguiente contenido:\n\nCreative Commons Youtube\nUsuario -
