Allen, Szilvia Benko, Laszlo Nagy.\n\nPublished in IMMUNITY - Cell Press (January 16, 2018): https://doi.org/10.1016/j.immuni.2017.12.010\n\nVIDEO ABSTRACT\nProduction Company: In Motion Science (IMS) - 2018\nhttps://www.imsprod.com/\nEmail: contact@imsprod.com", "defaultLanguage": "en", "channelTitle": "In Motion Science", "tags": ["Research", "Immunity", "Cell Press", "Science", "STAT6", "Macrophage", "Inflammation", "IL4", "Transcription factor", "IL1Beta", "Inflammasome", "IMS", "In Motion Science", "Video Abstract", "Motion Design", "Motion Graphics", "Molecular Biology", "Immunology", "Biology", "Research Article"], "defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "publishedAt": "2018-07-26T12:39:34Z", "channelId": "UCayETpdTfPgnjlqS2mh1fEg", "title": "STAT6 mediates repression of inflammatory enhancers and limits activation of macrophages"}, "id": "j9_CboLKTRs", "statistics": {"commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "642", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "likeCount": "14"}}]}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.12.010", "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.12.010", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT4M52S"}, "snippet": {"description": "BCG (Bacillus Calmette\u2013Gu\u00e9rin) Vaccine \u0995\u09bf \u09b8\u09a4\u09cd\u09af\u09bf CoronaVirus (COVID-19) \u09b0\u09cb\u0997\u09c7\u09b0 \u098f\u0995\u09ae\u09be\u09a4\u09cd\u09b0 \u099a\u09bf\u0995\u09bf\u09ce\u09b8\u09be ?\n\nThere is no evidence that the Bacille Calmette-Gu\u00e9rin vaccine (BCG) protects people against infection with the COVID-19 virus. Two clinical trials addressing this question are underway, and the WHO will evaluate the evidence when it is available. In the absence of evidence, the WHO does not recommend BCG vaccination for the prevention of COVID-19. WHO continues to recommend neonatal BCG vaccination in countries or settings with a high incidence of tuberculosis.\n\nThere is experimental evidence from both animal and human studies that the BCG vaccine has non-specific effects on the immune system. These effects have not been well characterized and their clinical relevance is unknown.\n\nOn 11 April 2020, WHO updated its ongoing evidence review of the major scientific databases and clinical trial repositories, using English, French and Chinese search terms for COVID-19, coronavirus, SARS-CoV-2 and BCG.\n\nThe review yielded three preprints (manuscripts posted online before peer-review), in which the authors compared the incidence of COVID-19 cases in countries where the BCG vaccine is used with countries where it is not used and observed that countries that routinely used the vaccine in neonates had less reported cases of COVID-19 to date. Such ecological studies are prone to significant bias from many confounders, including differences in national demographics and disease burden, testing rates for COVID-19 virus infections, and the stage of the pandemic in each country. \n\nThe review also yielded two registered protocols for clinical trials, both of which aim to study the effects of BCG vaccination given to health care workers directly involved in the care of patients with COVID-19.\n\nBCG vaccination prevents severe forms of tuberculosis in children and diversion of local supplies may result in neonates not being vaccinated, resulting in an increase of disease and deaths from tuberculosis. In the absence of evidence, the WHO does not recommend BCG vaccination for the prevention of COVID-19. WHO continues to recommend neonatal BCG vaccination in countries or settings with a high incidence of tuberculosis.\n\nReferences\n\n    BCG vaccines: WHO position paper \u2013 February 2018. "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT2M46S"}, "snippet": {"description": "Medicine by Alexandros G. Sfakianakis,Anapafseos 5 Agios Nikolaos 72100 Crete Greece,00306932607174,00302841026182,alsfakia@gmail.com\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nHead and neck squamous cell carcinoma of unknown primary: Outcomes of a pre-defined institutional treatment policy in a region with a high prevalence of skin cancer\r\nMichael Huo'Correspondence information about the author Michael HuoEmail the author Michael Huo, Benedict Panizza, Anne Bernard, Sandro V. Porceddu\r\nPlumX Metrics\r\nDOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.oraloncology.2017.12.011 \r\n\r\nHighlights\r\n\u2022Head and neck SCC of unknown primary presents a clinical dilemma.\r\n\u2022Patients may have risk factors for both cutaneous and mucosal primary sites.\r\n\u2022A treatment policy was developed in a region with a high prevalence of cutaneous SCC.\r\n\u2022Favourable rates of primary site control and nodal control were achieved.\r\nAbstract\r\nObjectives\r\nTo determine the rate of subsequent primary site failure in patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma of unknown primary (UKP HNSCC) in a region with a high prevalence of cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma, according to a pre-determined institutional policy. Secondary aims included regional and distant control, and overall survival.\r\n\r\nMaterial and methods\r\nPatients presenting between April 2005 and June 2016 to the Princess Alexandra Hospital Head and Neck Multidisciplinary Meeting with UKP HNSCC from either presumed mucosal or cutaneous sites treated with curative intent were eligible. Patients with presumed mucosal origin were treated with radiation therapy (RT) with or without chemotherapy, while patients with presumed cutaneous SCC were treated with surgery and post-operative RT with or without chemotherapy.\r\n\r\nResults\r\nA total of 63 patients met the inclusion criteria. Median follow up duration was 3.9\u202fyears (IQR 2.07-5.14). There were no subsequent primary site failures. The rate of nodal failure among presumed mucosal patients was 11.5%, and 8.1% among presumed cutaneous patients. The rate of distant metastatic failure was 11.1% among all patients. The estimated 5\u202fyear overall survival was 71.2% (95% CI 59.2\u201385.7%).\r\n\r\nConclusion\r\nTreatment according to our pre-defined institutional policy for UKP HNSCC in a region with a high prevalence of cutaneous SCC appears to be safe and effective with low rates of mucosal primary emergence and nodal failure.\r\n\r\nKeywords:\r\nHead and neck cancer, Unknown primary, Squamous cell carcinoma, Skin cancer, Oropharyngeal carcinoma, Radiotherapy\n\r\n\r- video upload powered by https://www.TunesToTube.com Medicine by Alexandros G. Estimating the Upper Limit of Lifetime Probability Distribution, Based on Data of Japanese Centenarians https://doi.org/10.1093/gerona/glv113", "channelTitle": "\u0412\u0441\u0435\u043b\u0435\u043d\u043d\u0430\u044f 42", "tags": ["\u0441\u0442\u0430\u0440\u0435\u043d\u0438\u0435", "\u0434\u043e\u043b\u0433\u043e\u043b\u0435\u0442\u0438\u0435", "\u0437\u0434\u043e\u0440\u043e\u0432\u044c\u0435", "\u0431\u0435\u0441\u0441\u043c\u0435\u0440\u0442\u0438\u0435", "\u0436\u0438\u0442\u044c\u0432\u0435\u0447\u043d\u043e", "\u0442\u0440\u0430\u043d\u0441\u0433\u0443\u043c\u0430\u043d\u0438\u0437\u043c", "\u0431\u0438\u043e\u0438\u043d\u0444\u0430\u0440\u043c\u0430\u0442\u0438\u043a\u0430", "\u043c\u043e\u0437\u0433", "\u043c\u0443\u0437\u0435\u0439\u043c\u043e\u0437\u0433\u0430", "\u043c\u0430\u0440\u0442\u044b\u043d\u043e\u0432", "\u043c\u0430\u043a\u0430\u0448\u043e\u0432", "\u0431\u0438\u0437\u0438\u043d", "\u0433\u0435\u043d", "\u0433\u0435\u043d\u0435\u0442\u0438\u043a\u0430", "\u0441\u0442\u0430\u0440\u043e\u0441\u0442\u044c"], "defaultAudioLanguage": "ru", "publishedAt": "2019-06-30T20:01:12Z", "channelId": "UCsYkWkT53X9q9vDuMmDacVQ", "title": "\u0411\u0435\u0441\u0441\u043c\u0435\u0440\u0442\u0438\u0435. \u0411\u0443\u0434\u0435\u043c \u043b\u0438 \u043c\u044b \u0436\u0438\u0442\u044c \u0432\u0435\u0447\u043d\u043e?"}, "id": "q-vWPxByrs0", "statistics": {"commentCount": "10", "viewCount": "875", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "3", "likeCount": "38"}}]}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.12.012", "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.12.012", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1H10M45S"}, "snippet": {"description": "Title: Determining uranium geochemistry within natural organic matter rich environments using XAS and XFM techniques\nSpeaker: Dr. Susan Cumberland (University of Strathclyde)\nAbstract: Analysing metals within environmental samples using wet chemistry can pose analytical problems, particularly with carbon-based and solid samples. X-ray absorbance spectroscopy (XAS) analysis is one alternative approach, able to target elements of interest whilst avoiding matrix interference from low mass elements (e.g. carbon). One element that is particularly suited to XAS is uranium (U), which is commonly investigated at the L3 edge. Understanding behaviour of U within the environment has been the focus of researchers for many decades, whether in exploration, mining, contamination, remediation or nuclear. Uranium geochemistry is the same regardless of whether its source is natural, depleted or as spent fuel, and the study of U is therefore multifaceted. In general terms, of the two main oxidation states, U(IV) and U(VI), U(IV) minerals have extremely low solubility, while U(VI) can be more soluble and therefore potentially mobilised.\nIn my work I have explored the nature of U within ore deposits, in particular the relationship between U and natural organic matter (OM) using XAS and X-ray fluorescence microscopy (XFM). OM may influence U mobility whether facilitating its pathway through the environment or acting as sink for U. In the case of the latter, OM may accumulate U over millennia within sediments or wetlands. Combining techniques from two beamlines at the Australian Synchrotron, XAS (XANES, EXAFS) and XFM (element mapping, \u00b5XANES), together with laboratory \u00b5XRD, spatial and chemical information were acquired on organically hosted U sediments taken from Mulga Rock Deposit, Western Australia. \nResults from XAS on bulk sample revealed how U at Mulga Rock is predominantly U(VI) within the OM sediments. However, from using \u00b5XANES transects across U on pyrite rims, we observe U(IV) outwardly transitioning to U(VI). Analysis of other features suggest that U has immortalised bacteria as coffinite (USiO4) ellipsoids. Furthermore, I show from laboratory experiments how OM may immobilise U(VI) rapidly without change in oxidation state. Thus, challenging traditional views that reduction of U(VI) to U(IV) has to occur for U to be immobilised within OM sediments. \nReading:\nCumberland, S.A., Douglas, G., Grice, K. and Moreau, J.W., 2016. Uranium mobility in organic matter-rich sediments: A review of geological and geochemical processes. Earth-Science Reviews, 159: 160-185. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.earscirev.2016.05.010\nCumberland, S.A., Etschmann, B., Brugger, J., Douglas, G., Evans, K., Fisher, L., Kappen, P. and Moreau, J.W., 2018a. Characterization of uranium redox state in organic-rich Eocene sediments. Chemosphere, 194: 602-613. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.chemosphere.2017.12.012\nCumberland, S.A., Wilson, S.A., Etschmann, B., Kappen, P., Howard, D., Paterson, D. and Brugger, J., 2018b. Rapid immobilisation of U(VI) by Eucalyptus bark: Adsorption without reduction. Applied Geochemistry, 96: 1-10. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.apgeochem.2018.05.023.\nCumberland, SA., Evans, K., Douglas, G., de Jonge, M., Fisher, L., Howard, D., Moreau., J. Characterisation of uranium-pyrite associations within organic-rich Eocene sediments using EM, XFM-\u03bcXANES and \u03bcXRD.  (submitted, Ore Geology Reviews)", "channelTitle": "Global XAS Journal Club", "tags": ["exafs", "actinide", "uranium geochemistry"], "publishedAt": "2020-08-13T00:49:28Z", "channelId": "snippet": {"description": "Read the paper here: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jamda.2017.12.014\n\nAnimation by www.AnimateYour.Science\n\nTranscript:\n\nFalls hurt everyone. \n\nThey harm the individual, those that care for them, as well as the broader community by placing an enormous strain on the health care system - more than any other trauma.\n\nWe can't stop ageing, but could we reduce the harmful and burdensome cost of falls?\n\nWe know that exercise can reduce our risk of falls, but there is an urgent lack of evidence for its usefulness in a residential care setting.\n\nSo a group of Australian researchers set out to test if an evidence-based strength and balance exercise program of 2 hours per week could reduce falls for residential care residents.\n\nThey randomly allocated 221 residents of 16 residential aged care facilities to either the Sunbeam Strength and Balance Program or the usual residential care, and compared the impact on both groups' falls over 12 months.\n\nThe results were nothing short of amazing.\n\nSunbeam participants experienced a staggering 55% fewer falls.\n\nThey also gained a significant boost to their physical performance, improving their opportunity to remain independent and participate in life.\n\nWhat's more, it's not only individuals who stand to benefit from such a program.\n\nIf the Sunbeam Strength and Balance Program was scaled nationally, the short and long term benefits would save the Australian Health Care Economy an estimated 120 million dollars.\n\nIt's clear. \n\nA tailored, evidence-based program of strength and balance exercises, prescribed by a physiotherapist, could dramatically improve the health and mobility of the world's elderly population.", "defaultLanguage": "en", "channelTitle": "Animate Your \u05d4\u05e7\u05d5\u05e8\u05d8\u05d9\u05d6\u05d5\u05dc \u05d4\u05d1\u05e1\u05d9\u05e1\u05d9 (\u05e7\u05d5\u05e8\u05d8\u05d9\u05d6\u05d5\u05dc \u05d1\u05e0\u05e7\u05d5\u05d3\u05ea \u05d6\u05de\u05df \u05d0\u05d7\u05ea), \u05d4\u05e7\u05d5\u05e8\u05d8\u05d9\u05d6\u05d5\u05dc \u05d4\u05dc\u05d0-\u05dc\u05d7\u05d5\u05e5 \u05dc\u05d0\u05d5\u05e8\u05da \u05d6\u05de\u05df (\u05e7\u05d5\u05e8\u05d8\u05d9\u05d6\u05d5\u05dc \u05e0\u05dc\u05db\u05d3 \u05d1\u05e9\u05ea\u05d9 \u05e0\u05e7\u05d5\u05d3\u05d5\u05ea \u05d6\u05de\u05df \u05d0\u05d5 \u05d9\u05d5\u05ea\u05e8) \u05d5\u05ea\u05d2\u05d5\u05d1\u05ea\u05d9\u05d5\u05ea \u05e9\u05dc \u05e7\u05d5\u05e8\u05d8\u05d9\u05d6\u05d5\u05dc \u05dc\u05e1\u05d8\u05e8\u05e1 \u05d7\u05e8\u05d9\u05e3 . \u05dc\u05d0 \u05e0\u05de\u05e6\u05d0 \u05e7\u05e9\u05e8 \u05de\u05d5\u05d1\u05d4\u05e7 \u05d1\u05d9\u05df ELS \u05dc- CAR , ELS \u05d5\u05e7\u05d5\u05e8\u05d8\u05d9\u05d6\u05d5\u05dc \u05e7\u05d5 Mas existe algu\u00e9m que gosta de mosquitos? Acho que n\u00e3o. Seus zumbidos s\u00e3o chatos, suas picadas causam irrita\u00e7\u00e3o e coceira, e o pior: podem transmitir doen\u00e7as como #dengue, chikungunya, #zika, mal\u00e1ria e febre amarela, por exemplo.\n\nNeste primeiro v\u00eddeo do meu canal eu respondo a uma das perguntas que mais recebo: por que os mosquitos gostam tanto da gente? Abordo o impacto do nosso #cheiro, a necessidade do mosquito consumir #sangue para consumir prote\u00ednas e se hidratar. Lozada'Correspondence information about the author Kirkland N. LozadaEmail the author Kirkland N. Lozada, Muhammed S. Qazi, Azita S. Khorsandi, Raymond L. Chai\r\nDOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.amjoto.2017.12.020\r\nshowArticle Info\r\nAbstract\r\nFull Text\r\nImages\r\nReferences\r\nAbstract\r\nImportance\r\nMucinous eccrine carcinoma is a rare entity that most commonly affects the head and neck. Due to its low frequency of occurrence, review of its etiology, histopathology, and treatment strategies is beneficial to all clinicians who may encounter similar appearing masses.\r\n\r\nObservation\r\nAn 84-year-old male presented with a blue mass on the left cheek. This mass started as a small bump and grew significantly over one year. His primary care physician monitored its growth and ultimately referred to an otolaryngologist. Imaging findings revealed a multi-lobular solid and cystic left buccal lesion. FNA was suggestive of low grade mucoepidermoid carcinoma.\r\n\r\nIntervention\r\nPatient underwent surgical excision with primary closure of the defect. Frozen section was consistent with low grade salivary malignancy. Final pathology revealed primary mucinous eccrine carcinoma of the skin.\r\n\r\nConclusions and relevance\r\nMucinous eccrine carcinoma is a rare entity commonly seen in the head and neck region. Mucinous deposits to the skin from primaries elsewhere in the body are much more common than primary lesions of the skin. Histology is a key component of the diagnosis but full oncologic workup is required. Treatment typically includes wide local excision with possible adjuvant chemotherapy or radiation for high risk features.\n\r\n\r- video upload powered by https://www.TunesToTube.com", "channelTitle": "Otolaryngologist,ORL,ENT-Medical Office,Artz Praxis", "tags": ["Primary", "mucinous", "eccrine", "carcinoma", "of", "the", "buccal", "space"], "publishedAt": "2018-01-08T13:04:39Z", "channelId": "UCQH21WX8Qn5YSTKrlJ3OrmQ", "title": "Primary mucinous eccrine carcinoma of the buccal space"}, "id": "kcO3sUd9RNY", "statistics": {"commentCount": "0", "viewCount": "83", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "likeCount": "1"}}]}, {"q": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.12.021", "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2017.12.021", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT13M43S"}, "snippet": {"description": "\ud83d\udc1d Subscribe for weekly #Zenthanol videos: https://www.youtube.com/user/Zenthanol\n\nSocial Media:\n\ud83e\udd8b Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Zenthanol \n\ud83d\udc1b Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/Zenthanol\n\ud83d\udc1c Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/synchangel (@Synchangel)\n\ud83d\udd77\ufe0f Soundcloud: https://soundcloud.com/synchangel\n\n--Literature Reference:  \n\nEngelhard B. 1996. Ataxite-like\nNWA 12769 Iron IVB Ataxite", "title": "Meteorites - The Beauty of Solar System Geology", "publishedAt": "2020-05-24T14:06:36Z", "channelTitle": "Ingo Schaefer", "channelId": "UCg3M9eLVUfABDNR4nJ6JWpg"}, "id": "x6g2bn7lspg", "statistics": {"commentCount": "2", "viewCount": "404", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "1", "likeCount": "5"}}]}, {"q": "10.1016/j.cma.2017.10.009", "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.cma.2017.10.009", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT13M47S"}, "snippet": {"description": "L'autophagie\u00a0est un ph\u00e9nom\u00e8ne de recyclage, de nettoyage cellulaire, d\u00e9clench\u00e9 par un manque d'apport de nourriture. Il y a trois formes d'autophagie\u00a0: la macro autophagie, la micro autophagie et l'autophagie m\u00e9diat\u00e9e par les prot\u00e9ines chaperons. \n\nL'autophagie est d\u00e9clench\u00e9e par\u00a0:\n- Augmentation AMPK AMP \"activated protein kinase\", qui est une\u00a0enzyme\u00a0intervenant dans le m\u00e9tabolisme \u00e9nerg\u00e9tique\n- Diminution de l'insuline \n- Diminution de MTor cible de la\u00a0rapamycine\u00a0chez les mammif\u00e8res, qui est une\u00a0enzyme\u00a0de la famille des\u00a0s\u00e9rine/thr\u00e9onine kinases\u00a0qui r\u00e9gule la\u00a0prolif\u00e9ration cellulaire, la\u00a0croissance cellulaire, la\u00a0mobilit\u00e9 cellulaire, la\u00a0survie cellulaire.\n\nC\u00e9tose\u00a0: \u00e9tat dans lequel on retrouve de nombreux corps c\u00e9toniques dans le sang. Les corps c\u00e9toniques servent de substrat \u00e9nerg\u00e9tique quand les r\u00e9serves de sucre sont \u00e9puis\u00e9es et sont produits par la d\u00e9gradation des lipides au niveau du foie. On assiste a une baisse de l'insuline, de mTor et augmentation de AMPK dans la mesure ou la r\u00e9ponse insulin\u00e9mique est plus faible avec les graisses que le sucre.\n\nC\u00e9tose et autophagie ne sont pas \u00e9quivalents mais il y a quand m\u00eame des corr\u00e9lations. Lorsque l'on je\u00fbne, d\u00e8s que les r\u00e9serves de sucre et glycog\u00e8ne sont \u00e9puis\u00e9es alors on passe en c\u00e9tose. Ces corps c\u00e9toniques en circulation favorisent \u00e9norm\u00e9ment de processus de d\u00e9toxification du corps.\n\nEn c\u00e9tose le niveau d'insuline et de mTor sont diminu\u00e9s, cela favorise l'autophagie. \n- https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/29056525\n- https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15883160\n\nAlors quoi manger\u00a0avant le je\u00fbne ? \u00c7a d\u00e9pend. Avant le je\u00fbne l'id\u00e9al est de favoriser une baisse des niveaux d'insuline qui va faire en sorte que l'on passera plus rapidement en autophagie, favoriser la c\u00e9tose en diminuant fortement les sucres dans les deux ou trois jours pr\u00e9c\u00e9dents. Et quoi consommer apr\u00e8s le je\u00fbne\u00a0? Tout d\u00e9pend de votre but. Pour sortir plus vite de l'\u00e9tat de je\u00fbne alors il est pr\u00e9f\u00e9rable de consommer du sucre pour faire remonter les niveaux d'insuline. Pour maintenir un max de temps l'autophagie et la lipolyse alors un r\u00e9gime pauvre en sucre et riche en graisses pour diminuer la r\u00e9ponse insulin\u00e9mique.\n\n________________\n\nJ'ai besoin de vous pour continuer \u00e0 diffuser gratuitement de l'information, merci pour vos dons !
